thread.title: Kodak u-turn as it announces it WILL bring back old-fashioned film almost five years after axing it for good
thread.title_full: Kodak u-turn as it announces it WILL bring back old-fashioned film almost five years after axing it for good

author: Ruki Sayid
title: Kodak u-turn as it announces it WILL bring back old-fashioned film almost five years after axing it for good
text:
Kodak have announced that they are bringing back photographic film to meet demand (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Kodak is bringing back old fashioned film after demand unexpectedly shot up. 
Almost five years after killing off its top notch Ektachrome film, the company has announced it will be back on shelves this year. 
Ektachrome - dubbed “the gold standard” by photographers - was the film of choice for glossy magazines like National Geographic for its vibrant colours, tones and quality. 
The revival follows a string of retro comebacks from vinyl records and hostess trolleys to fashion and sweets as nostalgic baby boomers long for a taste of their childhood while Millennials rebel against the digital age. 
Camera buffs will be thrilled to learn of Kodak’s U-turn and Steven Overman president of the Consumer and Film Division said: “We are seeing a broad resurgence of excitement about capturing images on film. Read More Kodak launches smartphone for photographers - can it compete with the likes of Apple and Samsung? Kodak's Ektachrome was axed five years ago (Photo: Getty) 
“Kodak is committed to continuing to manufacture film as an irreplaceable medium for image creators to capture their artistic vision. We are proud to help bring back this classic.” 
Although the popularity of digital cameras wiped out traditional film by 2003, figures show sales of Kodak Professional film jumped more than 5% worldwide between 2013 and 2015. Read More Vinyl sales reach highest level in last 25 years - with more than 3.2MILLION LPs sold last year 
In a statement Kodak Alaris - which has taken over the film branch of the business - said: “Sales of professional photographic films have been steadily rising over the last few years, with professionals and enthusiasts rediscovering the artistic control offered by manual processes and the creative satisfaction of a physical end product. 
“Resurgence in the popularity of analog photography has created demand for new and old film products alike.” Like us on Facebook
